Post Two in my series explaining who's who on a film shoot, and ever wonder who oversees the entire production process? Meet the Executive Producer. The Executive Producer, or EP, is more senior than a Producer and is the person behind the scenes ensuring a film gets made on time, on budget, and at the highest quality. Here‚Äôs what they do: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Secure Funding The EP‚Äôs first mission is often to find the money. Whether it‚Äôs from studios, investors, or brands, they make sure the project has the financial backing it needs to get off the ground. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Assemble the Team The EP hires the director, key crew members, and often the main cast. They bring together the right mix of talent to make the film or video shine. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Manage the Budget Once the money is secured, the EP keeps a close eye on the budget. They ensure that every penny is spent wisely and that there are no nasty financial surprises during the production. 4Ô∏è‚É£ Creative Oversight While they might not be involved in the day-to-day creative decisions, EPs have the final say on major creative aspects. They're there to ensure the film stays true to its vision and appeals to its target audience. 5Ô∏è‚É£ Problem Solver in Chief Every production hits a snag or two. The EP is the go-to person for solving problems, smoothing over conflicts, and keeping everything on track. 6Ô∏è‚É£ Marketing and Distribution After the film is made, the EP often plays a role in its marketing and distribution. They work to get the film seen by as many people as possible. Of course, roles and responsibilities can vary due to the type of project. In short though, the Executive Producer is the glue that holds the entire production together. They make tough decisions, manage finances, and ensure the project stays on course. I‚Äôm clearly biased (because I am one!), but having a strong EP is key to any successful production. Looking to hire an elite production crew to shoot a video for your business? Everyone is mad at Spotify again cuz they tried to flip the script on Phonorecords IV. But what is this Phonorecords IV, you ask? Phonorecords IV (CRB IV for the cool kids) is the latest contract in the music biz, all about the cash flow for tunesmiths and word weavers coming from those streaming giants we all hate, but vibe to begrudgingly - covering 2023 to 2027. This deal got cooked up after some fast but real talk between the National Music Publishers‚Äô Association (NMPA), the Nashville Songwriters Association International (NSAI), and the Digital Media Association‚Äîyeah, the backwards-hat wearing tech bros repping Spotify and Google. Here's why CRB IV is lit, and why it matters: ‚Ä¢ We're finally seeing a little bump in the payout for songwriters and publishers, with a headline rate of 15.35% for that five-year run. Not much, but better is better. ‚Ä¢ This deal got sealed way faster than the last one, Phonorecords III, which was like an endless encore nobody asked for. ‚Ä¢ The streamers have been hounded for the deets, which they wouldn‚Äôt give up, so SOMEBODY dropped an unredacted version of the agreement for all to peep. Yeah, the plot thickens right about here. The Copyright Royalty Board (CRB) stamped this bad boy with the official seal of approval. But, not everyone's throwing up peace signs. Some songwriters and their squads are throwing shade, calling for a total redo of how these rates get set - they‚Äôre not feeling the transparency or the terms. Now sure, dive into the nitty-gritty, and you'll find the 411 on stuff like "family plan‚Äù, "free trial offering," and "bundled subscription offerings," (which to be honest, is a pretty devious play on Spotify‚Äôs part) and penalties, late payments and the rates themselves. But this deal? It's a game-changer for the music makers and their bank accounts for the next few spins around the sun. So, what does Spotify decide to do? They‚Äôre shaking things up by calling its Premium plans 'bundles' now 'cause they're tossing in audiobooks. But here's the kicker (and where it gets confusing too): this switcheroo means the dough rolling out to songwriters is not as fat as the solo sub rate they all thumbs-upped in the CRB IV deal. And yeah, obviously that's got the NMPA throwing some serious side-eye, claiming Spotify's playing them dirty. But wait, there's more. Spotify's dropping a fresh audiobook-only tier and bumping up the price tag on all those Premium plans. And get this, to confuse you on the motivations of Spotify even more, a new 'Basic' tier is on the horizon too, serving up just the beats & podcasts, minus the bookish vibes. This one's apparently gonna stick to the full agreed payout rate for the lyrical geniuses and their paper-chasing pals. Despite stirring the pot, Spotify's all, ‚Äú(Spotify) is on track to pay publishers and societies more in 2024 than in 2023". And after already sliding nearly $4B to the rights holders in the last two years, maybe, just maybe, things are gonna get better?

The Future of Hollywood is Here! ‚Ä¶or it‚Äôs potential ruin...no big deal.ü§ó David Ellison taking charge of Paramount Pictures is a bigger deal than you might think. He‚Äôs got a chance to do something truly extraordinary. ‚Ä¢ Ellison plans to transform Paramount into a ‚Äútech hybrid‚Äù and he‚Äôs very qualified to do so. He is an experienced film producer and his dad is the co-founder of Oracle. ‚Ä¢ This means heavy use of AI, cloud computing, cutting edge virtual production and visual effects. What it should also mean is smart, savvy and creative marketing. ‚Ä¢ He has a respect for Paramount‚Äôs history, but maintains that nostalgia isn‚Äôt the way forward. So please let‚Äôs not remake Forrest Gump or have 15 more Top Guns. Keep making Mission Impossible though! ‚Ä¢ He‚Äôs gonna trim the fat. An estimated $2 billion of fat. Paramount is gonna be like Survivor for the foreseeable future. Good luck to everyone at Paramount, sharpen your spears and polish your resumes. ‚Ä¢ Can he make Paramount+ compete with Netflix, Hulu, Amazon Prime etc.? No he can‚Äôt, I think I got an offer for 3 free months of Paramount+ for ordering food on Uber Eats, I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs the path to success. ‚Ä¢ But maybe it can be part of something bigger and better, bundling is all the rage in streaming and sees much less churn. Sony? Starz? Does Microsoft wanna enter the biz? There's no doubt some form of partnership is necessary. All I know is he should do all or at least one of these three things: ‚Ä¢ Be the opposite of what everyone hates. *cough* Max app. *cough* Zaslav. *cough* Be the face of Paramount, endear yourself to the public, let us get to know you and especially your love for film, give us a top 5, show us your Criterion collection! ‚Ä¢ Go hard on video games, you‚Äôll sell more copies of a AAA game than box office tix. I want a Godfather open world GTA style game, a quirky Titanic Simulator where the ship sinks no matter what, and a Terminator survival game (take Last of Us and replace zombies with robots). ‚Ä¢ Focus on incredible stories and innovative filmmaking, give indie artists and student filmmakers a chance to shine on a big stage, let viewers connect with the day to day at the studio. All of this will create a community. And that‚Äôs what should separate Paramount from the other media giants. I've been very critical and dismissive of Paramount over the years(did we really need a remake of Ben-Hur?), but I want it to succeed. It's just too iconic to be salvaged for parts, there's so much history and so much potential. Don't mess it up Dave!

Movie theaters break records thanks to Wolverine and Deadpool https://ift.tt/vk09S2E Marvel‚Äôs Wolverine and Deadpool shattered box office records this weekend and movie theater companies are celebrating. The R-rated superhero action flick, produced by Marvel Studios and Disney, just had the sixth largest opening weekend of all-time in the U.S., generating $211 million in the domestic box office. It was also the largest opening for an R-rated film ever. Globally, the movie made $441.1 million. Execs at major movie theater companies in the U.S. are commemorating the movie‚Äôs success, as cinemas have struggled to maintain pre-pandemic attendance levels and are still recovering from the the Hollywood writers and actors strikes from last summer. ‚ÄúIt is certainly good news for those who care about AMC that with Deadpool & Wolverine we enjoyed the highest ever attendance and highest ever admissions revenue for the opening weekend of a rated-R movie in AMC‚Äôs company history, said Adam Aron, the chairman and CEO of AMC, the largest movie theater company in the U.S. Aron, added in a press release, that the company achieved its highest food and beverage revenue in a single weekend since 2019. Deadpool & Wolverine merch including multiple popcorn buckets also sold out. Premium format screenings, like IMAX, accounted for 18% of of the movies gross box office. ‚ÄúDeadpool & Wolverine delivered one of the biggest IMAX opening weekends of all time ‚Äî continuing our hot start to the third quarter and furthering our momentum ahead of a fantastic slate over the next several years,‚Äù said Rich Gelfond, CEO of IMAX, in a press release. IMAX said its screenings of the movie generated $36.5 million globally, making it its biggest July opening ever and its biggest debut weekend for and R-rated film. Wolverine and Deadpool also broke records at Cinemark for biggest summer weekend debut, largest opening for premium formats and motion seat screenings, and highest concessions revenue since the pandemic. From co-writing sessions to remote collaborations facilitated by digital platforms, these partnerships fuel creativity, foster innovation, and cultivate vibrant communities within the industry. The music production landscape reflects an ever-expanding tapestry of cultural diversity and inclusion. Artists draw inspiration from a myriad of cultural influences, infusing their work with rich textures and vibrant narratives. This celebration of diversity not only enriches the creative landscape but also resonates with audiences worldwide, fostering connections and understanding across borders. As we navigate the dynamic currents of the entertainment industry in 2024, music production emerges as a beacon of innovation and creativity. From technological advancements to cultural diversity, the landscape continues to evolve, presenting boundless opportunities for artists, producers, and industry professionals alike
